Hey @Xichen96 @yxieca @Blueve 
Is this test relevant only for m0 topo? If yes, please explain why.

Thank you

@AharonMalkin Some Intel CPUs are found to have caused problems when they enter certain idle state. We disable idle driver as a precaution. We start from M0 and Mx because they are weaker devices with less implecations. Ideally, we wouldn't want our management devices to sleep at all.

Hi @ayurkiv-nvda - what you observed was exactly the intention of this PR. 

Take server 192.168.0.3 for example. The report shows it had one disruption and it lasted for ~11seconds. 
```
18:58:52 dual_tor_io.examine_flow L0615 INFO | Server 192.168.0.3 results:
{
 "sent_packets": 625,
 "disruption_after_traffic": false,
 "disruptions": [
 {
 "start_time": 1697212533.826062,
 "start_id": 97,
 "end_time": 1697212545.712375,
 "end_id": 143
 }
 ],
 "duplications": [],
 "disruption_before_traffic": false,
 "received_packets": 580
}
```

The `allowed_disruptions` is 3 for this test. So the total disruption length allowed is 3*10s=30s, which is greater than 11, so the test passed. 
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/c071a76e45e559109a63b5316dd7fc7eb100ad11/tests/dualtor_io/test_link_failure.py#L49-L53

Hello @zjswhhh 
My understanding is that 10 seconds is the maximum possible disruption period.
And, separately, 3 disruptions are the maximum number of disruptions allowed.

So, according to this logic test should be considered as FAILED when the duration of the disruption is more than 10 seconds, OR when the number of disruptions is more than 3 (even if the total disruption duration is less than 10 seconds.)

In our lab real disruption time is 1-2 second. If it is bigger than 10 seconds, probably something bad happened.
It is the period during which Standby port becomes Active. 
Action of switching from Standby to active is related to ICMP heartbeat or link failure, so it should be done quickly. 

Before this PR was introduced we managed to find real bug on our platform (port wasn't triggered to Active properly and traffic was dropped for a long time). Without this change test has false-positive results.

Hi @ayurkiv-nvda - Thanks for the input! 

The reason we introduced this change is in our lab, we saw two expected consecutive toggles causing a long disruption, i.e the 1st one took 5 seconds and the 2nd one took 6 seconds. Though the duration is longer than 10s, we consider it as a pass. 

Disruption for link failure varies from case to case. Based on your input, I think what we need to re-evaluate is `MUX_SIM_ALLOWED_DISRUPTION_SEC`. A single switchover may not cost as much as 10 seconds.

@rraghav-cisco We saw regression caused by this PR.
As far as I understand, there may be some issue in function `get_multiple_flows`. In below `while` loop, you are updating the `src_ip` (from `192.0.0.0` to `192.0.0.255`) in each iteration, and expect the egress port to equal with `dst_id`. 
I think that logic is not reliable, cause that highly relys on the hashing algorithm. It's not assured that the packet will finally hit the expected port.
At least on our testbed, we saw the endless loop. 
https://github.com/rraghav-cisco/sonic-mgmt/blob/78baeb6465c9c15c2fa72f184262656f4a4ced37/tests/saitests/py3/sai_qos_tests.py#L169
```
while (num_of_pkts < packets_per_port):
 ip_Addr = next(IP_ADDR)
 pkt_args = {
 'ip_ecn':ecn,
 'ip_ttl':ttl,
 ......
 if get_rx_port_pkt(dp, src_tuple[0], pkt, masked_exp_pkt) == dst_id:
 try:
 all_pkts[src_tuple[0]].append((pkt, masked_exp_pkt))
 num_of_pkts+=1
 except KeyError:
 all_pkts[src_tuple[0]] = []
 all_pkts[src_tuple[0]].append((pkt, masked_exp_pkt.exp_pkt))
 num_of_pkts+=1
```
Can you please check and reply? Thanks

Thanks @rraghav-cisco 
I saw the endless on a T0 testbed. 

> I will add a check to stop the infinite loop after 500 ip addresses, if that is ok. If none of the 500 src addresses work(the dst_port_id never got any of the packets, but there is other ports receive all the packets), then this is a problem, and a RuntimeError will be raised.

This check looks good to me. But I still suggest limiting the change to multiasic for now, as we did in PR https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/8774.
